pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 121, 648, 146]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge International AS & A Level

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 171, 185, 189]]<|/det|>
PHYSICS Paper 1 Multiple Choice

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[869, 172, 908, 186]]<|/det|>
9702/12

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[734, 193, 908, 209]]<|/det|>
February/March 2025 1 hour 15 minutes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[98, 248, 509, 266]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[98, 279, 438, 296]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet Soft clean eraser

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 306, 540, 323]]<|/det|>
Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 337, 231, 353]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 353, 601, 372]]<|/det|>
- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. - For each question there are four possible answers \(\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B}, \mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\). Choose the one you consider correct

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 382, 682, 399]]<|/det|>
and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet. - Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 413, 277, 430]]<|/det|>
- Write in soft pencil. - Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 442, 521, 459]]<|/det|>
spaces provided unless this has been done for you. - Do not use correction fluid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 474, 369, 491]]<|/det|>
- Do not write on any bar codes. - You may use a calculator.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 536, 222, 549]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 548, 393, 567]]<|/det|>
- The total mark for this paper is 40. - Each correct answer will score one mark.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 579, 572, 596]]<|/det|>
- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 74, 126, 89]]<|/det|>
Data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 102, 272, 116]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g=9.81 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 135, 306, 150]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c=3.00 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 168, 238, 181]]<|/det|>
elementary charge \(e=1.60 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 200, 267, 214]]<|/det|>
unified atomic mass unit \(1 \mathrm{u}=1.66 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{~kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 232, 267, 247]]<|/det|>
rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}}=1.67 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{~kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 265, 256, 279]]<|/det|>
rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}}=9.11 \times 10^{-31} \mathrm{~kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 297, 239, 311]]<|/det|>
Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}}=6.02 \times 10^{23} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 330, 239, 344]]<|/det|>
molar gas constant \(R=8.31 \mathrm{~JK}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 361, 247, 376]]<|/det|>
Boltzmann constant \(k=1.38 \times 10^{-23} \mathrm{~JK}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 394, 261, 408]]<|/det|>
gravitational constant \(G=6.67 \times 10^{-11} \mathrm{Nm}^{2} \mathrm{~kg}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 427, 286, 442]]<|/det|>
permittivity of free space \(\varepsilon_{0}=8.85 \times 10^{-12} \mathrm{~Fm}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[413, 447, 631, 478]]<|/det|>
\[
(\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}}=8.99 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{~mF}^{-1})
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 495, 217, 508]]<|/det|>
Planck constant \(h=6.63 \times 10^{-34} \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 526, 311, 543]]<|/det|>
Stefan-Boltzmann constant \(\sigma=5.67 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~W} \mathrm{~m}^{-2} \mathrm{~K}^{-4}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 587, 168, 601]]<|/det|>
Formulae

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 614, 322, 629]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion \(s=u t+\frac{1}{2} a t^{2}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 632, 565, 649]]<|/det|>
\[
v^{2}=u^{2}+2 a s
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 665, 250, 680]]<|/det|>
hydrostatic pressure \(\Delta p=\rho g \Delta h\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 696, 154, 711]]<|/det|>
upthrust \(F=\rho g V\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 726, 339, 743]]<|/det|>
Doppler effect for sound waves \(f_{0}=\frac{f_{s} v}{v \pm v_{s}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 767, 209, 780]]<|/det|>
electric current \(I=A n v q\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 797, 228, 812]]<|/det|>
resistors in series \(R=R_{1}+R_{2}+ \ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 823, 239, 840]]<|/det|>
resistors in parallel \(\frac{1}{R}=\frac{1}{R_{1}}+\frac{1}{R_{2}}+\ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 410, 91]]<|/det|>
\(1 \quad\) Which quantity is a scalar quantity?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 198, 116]]<|/det|>
A force

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 128, 248, 142]]<|/det|>
B momentum

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 154, 217, 169]]<|/det|>
C velocity

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 179, 195, 192]]<|/det|>
D work

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 224, 797, 241]]<|/det|>
2 What is the effect of a systematic error on the measurement of a physical quantity?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 252, 515, 269]]<|/det|>
A It limits the precision of the measured value.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 278, 681, 294]]<|/det|>
B It limits the range of values obtained in repeated measurements.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 302, 780, 321]]<|/det|>
C It results in repeated measurements having different values from each other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 330, 725, 346]]<|/det|>
D It results in the measured value being different from the correct value.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 374, 667, 392]]<|/det|>
3 A car is accelerated by a constant resultant force of 300 N for 5.0 s .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 402, 671, 421]]<|/det|>
The variation with time of the velocity, in \(\mathrm{cm} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\), of the car is shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[327, 433, 672, 607]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 622, 355, 637]]<|/det|>
What is the mass of the car?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 652, 201, 667]]<|/det|>
A 13 kg

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 652, 388, 667]]<|/det|>
B 1000 kg

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 652, 554, 667]]<|/det|>
C 1300 kg

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 652, 734, 667]]<|/det|>
D 10000 kg

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 695, 918, 712]]<|/det|>
4 An aircraft, initially stationary on a runway, takes off with a speed of \(85 \mathrm{kmh}^{-1}\) in a distance of no more than 1.20 km .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 741, 692, 758]]<|/det|>
What is the minimum constant acceleration necessary for the aircraft?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 767, 236, 783]]<|/det|>
A \(0.23 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 767, 402, 783]]<|/det|>
B \(\quad 0.46 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 767, 559, 783]]<|/det|>
C \(3.0 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 767, 725, 783]]<|/det|>
D \(6.0 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 72, 920, 91]]<|/det|>
5 An object is fired upwards from horizontal ground. The object has an initial velocity of \(20 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) at an angle of \(45^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. Air resistance is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
Which statement describes the speed of the object after it is fired until immediately before it reaches the ground again?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 160, 778, 179]]<|/det|>
A Its speed decreases to a value greater than zero, then increases to \(20 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 187, 918, 204]]<|/det|>
B Its speed decreases to a value greater than zero, then increases to a value greater than \(20 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 226, 609, 245]]<|/det|>
C Its speed decreases to zero, then increases to \(20 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 251, 753, 270]]<|/det|>
D Its speed decreases to zero, then increases to a value less than \(20 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 298, 775, 315]]<|/det|>
6 What is a statement of the principle of conservation of momentum for a system?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 326, 742, 344]]<|/det|>
A The total momentum and the total kinetic energy are always conserved.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 353, 635, 370]]<|/det|>
B The total momentum is conserved only in elastic collisions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 378, 734, 395]]<|/det|>
C The total momentum is conserved provided that no external forces act.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 404, 877, 421]]<|/det|>
D The total momentum of each object in the system is the product of its mass and velocity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 449, 461, 466]]<|/det|>
7 Objects P and Q form an isolated system.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 478, 640, 497]]<|/det|>
Object \(P\) has mass 6.0 kg and is moving at a speed of \(3.0 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 507, 918, 526]]<|/det|>
Object Q has mass 2.0 kg and is moving at a speed of \(4.2 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\) at an angle of \(35^{\circ}\) to the path of \(P\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[325, 554, 673, 672]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 688, 469, 704]]<|/det|>
Objects P and Q collide and stick together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 718, 918, 735]]<|/det|>
What is the magnitude of the component of the final momentum of the combined objects in the original direction of P ?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 759, 248, 778]]<|/det|>
A \(9.6 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 759, 411, 778]]<|/det|>
B \(11 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 759, 576, 778]]<|/det|>
C \(13 \mathrm{kgm} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 759, 742, 778]]<|/det|>
D \(25 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
8 An astronaut of mass \(m\) in a spacecraft experiences a gravitational force \(F=m g\) when stationary on the launchpad.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
What is the gravitational force on the astronaut when the spacecraft is launched vertically upwards with an acceleration of \(0.2 g\) ?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 162, 209, 179]]<|/det|>
A 1.2 mg

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 162, 350, 179]]<|/det|>
B \(m g\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 162, 543, 179]]<|/det|>
C 0.8 mg

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 162, 669, 178]]<|/det|>
D 0

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 207, 918, 223]]<|/det|>
9 The diagram shows a child \(X\) of mass 20 kg and a child \(Y\) of mass 15 kg seated on a uniform plank.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[278, 251, 716, 392]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 404, 918, 421]]<|/det|>
The plank has a mass of 7.0 kg and has a pivot at its midpoint. The plank is horizontal and in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 451, 590, 467]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the weight of the plank is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 478, 728, 495]]<|/det|>
A The weight of the plank can be considered to be acting at its midpoint.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 503, 650, 520]]<|/det|>
B The weight of the plank is causing an anticlockwise moment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 529, 609, 546]]<|/det|>
C The weight of the plank is causing a clockwise moment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 555, 711, 571]]<|/det|>
D The weight of the plank equals the force on the plank from the pivot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 601, 438, 618]]<|/det|>
10 An object is fully submerged in a liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 628, 611, 665]]<|/det|>
A student determines the ratio \(\frac{\text { upthrust acting on the object }}{\text { weight of the object }}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 673, 590, 689]]<|/det|>
Which single change would double the value of this ratio?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 700, 892, 717]]<|/det|>
A Use a different liquid that has twice the density and the same volume as the original liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 726, 891, 743]]<|/det|>
B Use a different object that has half the volume and the same density as the original object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 752, 905, 768]]<|/det|>
C Use a different object that has twice the density and the same volume as the original object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 778, 905, 793]]<|/det|>
D Use a different object that has twice the volume and the same density as the original object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 74, 720, 91]]<|/det|>
11 A shop sign weighing 75 N hangs from a frame attached to a vertical wall.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 102, 721, 310]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 322, 918, 338]]<|/det|>
The frame consists of a horizontal rod \(X Y\) and a rod \(Y Z\) that is at an angle of \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. Rod XY is attached to the wall by a hinge at X and has length 0.50 m . Assume that the weights of

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 351, 308, 368]]<|/det|>
the rods are negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 382, 601, 399]]<|/det|>
What is the horizontal force exerted by the wall on r r Y ?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 410, 182, 425]]<|/det|>
A \(\quad 0 \mathrm{~N}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 410, 361, 425]]<|/det|>
B \(\quad 43 \mathrm{~N}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 410, 537, 425]]<|/det|>
C \(\quad 130 \mathrm{~N}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 410, 703, 425]]<|/det|>
D \(\quad 150 \mathrm{~N}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 454, 753, 471]]<|/det|>
12 A student takes measurements to calculate the density of a liquid in a beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 486, 548, 503]]<|/det|>
The height of the liquid in the beaker is \(0.20 \mathrm{~m} \pm 2 \%\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 517, 537, 532]]<|/det|>
The internal diameter of the beaker is \(0.05 \mathrm{~m} \pm 3 \%\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 548, 446, 565]]<|/det|>
The mass of the liquid is \(0.36 \mathrm{~kg} \pm 10 \%\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 577, 720, 595]]<|/det|>
What is the percentage uncertainty in the calculated density of the liquid?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 605, 184, 621]]<|/det|>
A \(2 \%\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 605, 350, 621]]<|/det|>
B 5\%

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 605, 526, 621]]<|/det|>
C 15\%

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 605, 695, 621]]<|/det|>
D 18\%

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 74, 720, 91]]<|/det|> 13 The diagram shows a uniform plank XY of length 4.0 m and weight 300 N . <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[244, 103, 756, 237]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 250, 556, 266]]<|/det|> The plank rests on fixed supports at its ends \(X\) and \(Y\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 279, 645, 297]]<|/det|> A child of weight 600 N stands in different positions on the plank. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 310, 689, 327]]<|/det|> The support at end \(X\) exerts a force \(F\) vertically upwards on the plank. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 339, 830, 356]]<|/det|> What is the magnitude of \(F\) when the child stands at X and when the child stands at Y ? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 368, 440, 512]]<|/det|>
\(F / \mathrm{N}\) when
child is at X
\(F / \mathrm{N}\) when
child is at Y
A
600
0
B
600
150
C
750
0
D
750
150
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 540, 667, 557]]<|/det|> 14 Which relationship is used in the derivation of the equation shown? <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[399, 572, 601, 588]]<|/det|> \[ \text { power }=\text { force } \times \text { velocity } \] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 603, 405, 620]]<|/det|> A displacement \(=\) velocity \(\times\) time <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 630, 382, 645]]<|/det|> B force \(=\) mass \(\times\) acceleration <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 657, 395, 672]]<|/det|> C momentum \(=\) mass \(\times\) velocity <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 683, 395, 700]]<|/det|> D velocity \(=\) acceleration \(\times\) time

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
15 A block is released from rest at the top of a slope inclined at an angle to the horizontal. The slope has length \(L\) as shown in the diagram.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[365, 118, 631, 228]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 240, 518, 257]]<|/det|>
There are no resistive forces acting on the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 271, 592, 287]]<|/det|>
What is the speed of the block at the bottom of the slope?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 300, 261, 319]]<|/det|>
A \(4.43 \sqrt{L \cos \theta}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 300, 423, 319]]<|/det|>
B \(4.43 \sqrt{L \sin \theta}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 302, 579, 317]]<|/det|>
C \(19.6 L \cos \theta\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 302, 739, 319]]<|/det|>
D \(19.6 L \sin \theta\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 349, 918, 366]]<|/det|>
16 A skateboarder and her skateboard have a total mass of 70 kg . She pushes on the ground with her foot to create a forward force \(F\) of 25 N on herself and the skateboard, as shown in the

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 380, 192, 397]]<|/det|>
diagram.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[364, 408, 637, 579]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 595, 918, 610]]<|/det|>
The skateboarder and skateboard travel forwards a distance of 0.50 m before the skateboarder lifts her foot from the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 640, 656, 657]]<|/det|>
What is the work done by \(F\) on the skateboarder and skateboard?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 667, 190, 682]]<|/det|>
A 13 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 667, 355, 682]]<|/det|>
B 50 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 667, 532, 682]]<|/det|>
C 340 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 667, 698, 682]]<|/det|>
D 360 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 713, 918, 729]]<|/det|>
17 A turbine at a hydroelectric power station is situated at a vertical distance of 30 m below the level of the surface of a large lake. The water passes through the turbine at a rate of

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 741, 272, 758]]<|/det|>
\(340 \mathrm{~m}^{3}\) per minute.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 772, 918, 790]]<|/det|>
The overall efficiency of the turbine and generator system is \(90 \%\). The density of water is \(1000 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 816, 556, 834]]<|/det|>
What is the useful power output of the power station?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 845, 228, 860]]<|/det|>
A \(\quad 0.15 \mathrm{MW}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 845, 385, 860]]<|/det|>
B \(\quad 1.5 \mathrm{MW}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 845, 551, 860]]<|/det|>
C \(\quad 1.7 \mathrm{MW}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 845, 714, 860]]<|/det|>
D 90 MW

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 74, 728, 91]]<|/det|>
18 A projectile is launched at \(45^{\circ}\) to the horizontal with initial kinetic energy \(E\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 105, 918, 121]]<|/det|>
Assuming air resistance to be negligible, what will be the kinetic energy of the projectile when it reaches its highest point?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 146, 206, 161]]<|/det|>
A \(0.50 E\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 146, 372, 161]]<|/det|>
B \(0.71 E\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 146, 539, 161]]<|/det|>
C \(0.87 E\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[618, 146, 671, 161]]<|/det|>
D \(E\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 193, 683, 208]]<|/det|>
19 A wire is extended by a tensile force so that its deformation is elastic.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 222, 432, 239]]<|/det|>
What is meant by elastic deformation?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 250, 645, 266]]<|/det|>
A The extension of the wire is proportional to the tensile force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 275, 678, 291]]<|/det|>
B The extension of the wire is not proportional to the tensile force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 300, 811, 317]]<|/det|>
C When the tensile force is removed, the wire does not return to its original length.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 326, 742, 344]]<|/det|>
D When the tensile force is removed, the wire returns to its original length.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 372, 504, 389]]<|/det|>
20 A bolt is subjected to a tensile force, as shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[228, 402, 770, 520]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 533, 888, 549]]<|/det|>
The bolt has a circular cross-section. At end X , the diameter is \(2 d\). At end Y , the diameter is \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 567, 366, 598]]<|/det|>
What is the ratio \(\frac{\text { stress at } Y}{\text { stress at } X}\) ?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 611, 192, 626]]<|/det|>
A 0.25

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 611, 358, 626]]<|/det|>
B 0.50

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 611, 515, 626]]<|/det|>
C 2.0

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 611, 681, 626]]<|/det|>
D 4.0

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|> 21 The graph shows the relationship between force acting on a compression spring and change in length of the spring. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[189, 118, 808, 472]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 486, 918, 503]]<|/det|> One of these springs is placed in each corner of a horizontal square plate. The axis of each spring is in a vertical direction. These four springs support a total load of 160 N . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 533, 667, 549]]<|/det|> What is the total elastic potential energy stored in the four springs? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 560, 214, 575]]<|/det|> A \(\quad 0.048 \mathrm{~J}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 560, 372, 575]]<|/det|> B \(\quad 0.19 \mathrm{~J}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 560, 537, 575]]<|/det|> C 0.38J <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 560, 706, 575]]<|/det|> D \(\quad 0.77 \mathrm{~J}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 605, 725, 621]]<|/det|> 22 Which row correctly identifies the properties of all electromagnetic waves? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 633, 908, 779]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 793, 91]]<|/det|>
23 What is the approximate range of wavelengths in free space for infrared radiation?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 300, 116]]<|/det|>
A 100 nm to 400 nm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 128, 289, 146]]<|/det|>
B \(300 \mu \mathrm{~m}\) to 30 cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 154, 300, 169]]<|/det|>
C 400 nm to 700 nm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 181, 311, 198]]<|/det|>
D 800 nm to \(1000 \mu \mathrm{~m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 226, 918, 243]]<|/det|>
24 The diagram shows a car travelling at a constant speed in a straight line between person P and person Q from point X to point Y .

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 269, 844, 372]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 384, 896, 401]]<|/det|>
The car sounds its horn continuously as it travels. The horn emits sound of constant frequency.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 415, 918, 430]]<|/det|>
Which statements about what person P and person Q hear during the motion of the car are correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 460, 626, 477]]<|/det|>
1 Person P hears a sound of increasing frequency.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 486, 634, 502]]<|/det|>
2 Person Q hears a sound of decreasing frequency.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 511, 778, 528]]<|/det|>
3 Person Q always hears a sound of higher frequency than person P .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 540, 239, 555]]<|/det|>
A 1,2 and 3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 567, 258, 583]]<|/det|>
B 1 and 2 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 593, 206, 608]]<|/det|>
C 3 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 618, 264, 633]]<|/det|>
D none of them

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 661, 761, 680]]<|/det|>
25 A progressive wave of frequency 300 Hz is travelling with a speed of \(600 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 693, 918, 709]]<|/det|>
What is the phase difference between two points on the wave that are a distance of 0.50 m apart?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 722, 184, 735]]<|/det|>
A \(45^{\circ}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 722, 350, 735]]<|/det|>
B \(90^{\circ}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 722, 526, 735]]<|/det|>
C \(180^{\circ}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 722, 695, 735]]<|/det|>
D \(360^{\circ}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 780, 91]]<|/det|> 26 A polarised beam of light with intensity \(I\) is incident normally on a polarising filter. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 105, 413, 122]]<|/det|> The transmitted light has intensity \(I\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 136, 620, 153]]<|/det|> The filter is rotated about the normal axis through an angle \(\theta\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 168, 449, 184]]<|/det|> The transmitted light has intensity \(0.75 I\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 199, 291, 216]]<|/det|> What is the angle \(\theta\) ? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 226, 184, 242]]<|/det|> A \(30^{\circ}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 226, 350, 241]]<|/det|> B \(42^{\circ}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 226, 518, 242]]<|/det|> C \(49^{\circ}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 226, 684, 241]]<|/det|> D \(60^{\circ}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 271, 466, 288]]<|/det|> 27 Light waves are emitted from two sources. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 302, 791, 318]]<|/det|> What is a necessary condition for observable interference fringes to be produced? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 330, 402, 346]]<|/det|> A The waves must be polarised. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 355, 435, 372]]<|/det|> B The waves must not be polarised. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 380, 399, 395]]<|/det|> C The waves must be coherent. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 407, 485, 423]]<|/det|> D The waves must have equal amplitudes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 451, 918, 469]]<|/det|> 28 The diagram shows a water wave in a shallow tank. The wave is diffracted through a gap in a barrier and spreads. The wavelength of the wave is much smaller than the width of the gap. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 493, 573, 615]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 626, 863, 643]]<|/det|> The wavelength of the wave and the width of the gap are both changed by a small amount. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 657, 852, 673]]<|/det|> Which combination of changes must increase the amount of spreading due to diffraction? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 685, 450, 813]]<|/det|>
wavelength
width of gap
A
decreases
decreases
B
decreases
increases
C
increases
decreases
D
increases
increases

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|> 29 Light of wavelength 567 nm is incident normally on a diffraction grating. The grating has 400 linesper mm. A number of diffraction maxima are observed on the far side of the grating. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 822, 136]]<|/det|> What is the angle between the second-order maximum and the third-order maximum? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 146, 201, 161]]<|/det|> A \(\quad 13.1^{\circ}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 146, 366, 161]]<|/det|> B \(13.9^{\circ}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 146, 532, 161]]<|/det|> C \(\quad 15.9^{\circ}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 146, 700, 161]]<|/det|> D \(27.0^{\circ}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 192, 918, 208]]<|/det|> 30 Two cylindrical conductors, \(X\) and \(Y\), are made from the same material. The conductors have equal lengths, but \(Y\) has a smaller diameter than \(X\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 238, 457, 253]]<|/det|> \(X\) and \(Y\) are connected in series to a cell. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 267, 918, 284]]<|/det|> Which row compares the number of charge carriers per unit time passing through X and through Y and compares the average drift speed of the charge carriers in X and in Y ? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 310, 583, 456]]<|/det|>
number of charge carriers per unit time

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[182, 318, 358, 351]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 361, 153, 377]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 386, 153, 402]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 411, 153, 427]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 436, 153, 453]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 486, 601, 502]]<|/det|> 31 A copper wire is 6.4 m long and has a resistance of \(0.92 \Omega\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 513, 460, 532]]<|/det|> The resistivity of copper is \(1.8 \times 10^{-8} \Omega \mathrm{~m}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 546, 391, 561]]<|/det|> What is the diameter of the wire? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 574, 256, 590]]<|/det|> A \(5.7 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{~m}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 574, 421, 590]]<|/det|> B \(\quad 1.0 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~m}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 574, 590, 590]]<|/det|> C \(\quad 4.0 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~m}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 574, 755, 590]]<|/det|> D \(\quad 7.1 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 678, 91]]<|/det|>
32 A thermistor is connected to a cell with negligible internal resistance.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[421, 103, 579, 195]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 209, 869, 223]]<|/det|>
Which graph shows the variation with temperature of power, \(P\), dissipated in the thermistor?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[334, 236, 356, 252]]<|/det|>
A

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[243, 254, 452, 380]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[643, 236, 658, 252]]<|/det|>
B

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 254, 758, 380]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[334, 413, 353, 425]]<|/det|>
C

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[240, 429, 452, 555]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[642, 413, 658, 425]]<|/det|>
D

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 427, 758, 555]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 587, 918, 603]]<|/det|>
33 A metal electrical conductor has a resistance of \(5.6 \mathrm{k} \Omega\). A potential difference (p.d.) of 9.0 V is applied across its ends.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 632, 656, 649]]<|/det|>
How many electrons pass a point in the conductor in one minute?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 659, 239, 674]]<|/det|>
A \(6.0 \times 10^{20}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 659, 405, 674]]<|/det|>
B \(1.0 \times 10^{19}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 659, 572, 674]]<|/det|>
C \(6.0 \times 10^{17}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[618, 659, 736, 674]]<|/det|>
D \(1.0 \times 10^{16}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 706, 918, 722]]<|/det|>
34 Which circuit symbol does not represent an electric component that is designed to emit sound waves?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[244, 752, 264, 765]]<|/det|>
A

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[223, 784, 283, 818]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[410, 752, 428, 765]]<|/det|>
B

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[360, 792, 477, 808]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[574, 751, 591, 765]]<|/det|>
C

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[555, 780, 606, 821]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 752, 758, 765]]<|/det|>
D

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[718, 784, 772, 815]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
35 The diagram shows a junction in a circuit where three wires, \(P, Q\) and \(R\), meet. The currents in \(P\) and Q are 1 A and 3 A respectively, in the directions shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[310, 118, 690, 248]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 265, 653, 282]]<|/det|>
How much charge passes a given point in wire \(R\) in a time of \(5 s\) ?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 295, 198, 307]]<|/det|>
A \(\quad 0.4 \mathrm{C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 295, 350, 307]]<|/det|>
B 2C

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 295, 526, 307]]<|/det|>
C \(\quad 10 \mathrm{C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 295, 692, 307]]<|/det|>
D 20 C

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 339, 918, 354]]<|/det|>
36 A cell of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(E\) and internal resistance \(r\) is connected in series with a switch \(S\) and an external resistor of resistance \(R\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[368, 380, 631, 518]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 531, 551, 547]]<|/det|>
The potential difference (p.d.) between P and Q is \(V\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 560, 678, 577]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct when \(S\) is changed from open to closed?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 589, 526, 604]]<|/det|>
A \(V\) increases because there is a p.d. across \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 614, 526, 630]]<|/det|>
B \(V\) decreases because there is a p.d. across \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 640, 921, 657]]<|/det|>
C \(V\) remains the same because the decrease of p.d. across \(r\) is balanced by the increase of p.d. across \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 681, 833, 696]]<|/det|>
D \(V\) remains the same because the sum of the p.d.s across \(r\) and \(R\) is still equal to \(E\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 726, 466, 743]]<|/det|>
37 What is a general description of a baryon?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 754, 648, 770]]<|/det|>
A It consists of three quarks that must all be the same flavour.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 780, 700, 795]]<|/det|>
B It consists of three quarks that do not need to be the same flavour.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 806, 650, 821]]<|/det|>
C It consists of two quarks that must both be the same flavour.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 831, 686, 847]]<|/det|>
D It consists of two quarks that do not need to be the same flavour.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 482, 89]]<|/det|>
38 A stationary nucleus has nucleon number \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 918, 120]]<|/det|>
The nucleus decays by emitting a proton with speed \(v\) to form a new nucleus with speed \(u\). The new nucleus and the proton move away from one another in opposite directions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 148, 482, 166]]<|/det|>
Which equation gives \(v\) in terms of \(A\) and \(u\) ?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 172, 263, 200]]<|/det|>
A \(\quad v=\left(\frac{A}{4}-1\right) u\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 205, 256, 222]]<|/det|>
B \(\quad v=(A-1) u\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 230, 211, 247]]<|/det|>
C \(\quad v=A u\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 256, 256, 274]]<|/det|>
D \(\quad v=(A+1) u\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 302, 869, 320]]<|/det|>
39 What is the change to the quark composition of a nucleus that takes place during \(\beta^{+}\)decay?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 331, 277, 348]]<|/det|>
A down to antiup

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 357, 247, 374]]<|/det|>
B down to up

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 382, 277, 399]]<|/det|>
C up to antidown

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 408, 247, 425]]<|/det|>
D up to down

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 452, 742, 469]]<|/det|>
40 What is the charge, in terms of the elementary charge \(e\), on a charm quark?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 486, 201, 518]]<|/det|>
A \(-\frac{2}{3} e\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[281, 486, 366, 518]]<|/det|>
B \(-\frac{1}{3} e\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[449, 486, 532, 518]]<|/det|>
C \(+\frac{1}{3} e\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 486, 700, 518]]<|/det|>
D \(+\frac{2}{3} e\)
